Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/sandboxir/passmanager-h/#l00197">197</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/sandboxir/passmanager-h">PassManager.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### setPassPipeline() {#a25d8acedc0fc6a1fbd8a2eea6dcd0f4c}

<MemberDefinition
  template={<>template &lt;typename ParentPass, typename ContainedPass&gt;</>}
  prototype={<>void llvm::sandboxir::PassManager&lt; ParentPass, ContainedPass &gt;::setPassPipeline (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/stringref">StringRef</a> Pipeline, <a href="#a49776eae204190a6aeb2bae228f7d938">CreatePassFunc</a> CreatePass)</>}
  labels = {["inline"]}>
Parses <code>Pipeline</code> as a comma-separated sequence of pass names and sets the pass pipeline, using <code>CreatePass</code> to instantiate passes by name.

Passes can have arguments, for example: &quot;pass1&lt;arg1,arg2&gt;,pass2,pass3&lt;arg3,arg4&gt;&quot;

The arguments between angle brackets are treated as a mostly opaque string and each pass is responsible for parsing its arguments. The exception to this are nested angle brackets, which must match pair-wise to allow arguments to contain nested pipelines, like:

&quot;pass1&lt;subpass1,subpass2&lt;arg1,arg2&gt;,subpass3&gt;&quot;

An empty args string is treated the same as no args, so &quot;pass&quot; and &quot;pass&lt;&gt;&quot; are equivalent.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/sandboxir/passmanager-h/#l00076">76</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/sandboxir/passmanager-h">PassManager.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

</SectionDefinition>
